article_text:
The Obama presidency doesn’t arrive in David Axelrod’s 500-page memoir, “Believer: My Forty Years in Politics,” until the book is about two-thirds over. But it is worth the wait, or at least the wading.

President Obama is in the middle of his fight to pass the Affordable Care Act. This is the book’s most politically compelling chapter, though the word “ObamaCare” is entirely absent. Some in the White House, such as chief of staff Rahm Emanuel, worry that the stumbling, unpopular effort to pass the ACA will damage...

article_summary:
The Obama presidency doesn’t arrive in David Axelrod’s 500-page memoir, “Believer: My Forty Years in Politics,” until the book is about two-thirds over.
Some in the White House, such as chief of staff Rahm Emanuel, worry that the stumbling, unpopular effort to pass the ACA will damage...
But it is worth the wait, or at least the wading.
President Obama is in the middle of his fight to pass the Affordable Care Act.
This is the book’s most politically compelling chapter, though the word “ObamaCare” is entirely absent.
